item.title: Plus Size Alternative Retro With Belle Poque
item.dc:creator: Melody Mae
item.description:
A style post on plus size alternative retro style with Belle Poque written by Andii Melody Mae on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a fat girl fashion blog

The post Plus Size Alternative Retro With Belle Poque appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
I’ll stop wearing black when they make a darker colour…

That’s a hilarious nod to Fall Out Boy, I promise. But hello friends! How are we all doing this weekend? I really can’t get my head back into the game with regularly posting on here; I wonder where I found the time before my hiatus. Between a full time job and staring at a kitten (yes, I’m still obsessed with my cat) I just can’t find the time these days… But let’s talk about some plus size alternative retro courtesy of Belle Poque!

This item was gifted in return for a review and images. Opinions are my own, I’m not paid to say anything in particular. Some links may be affiliate links, it just means I might get a few quid if you buy through my links. You can read more in my disclaimer.

Plus size alternative retro? What even is that?

My style has changed dramatically since the before-covid times. I’m sure a lot of us have a similar experience — either we’re all in love with loungewear, we finally started dressing how we always wanted, or our bodies and attitudes to clothing changed. Mine’s a bit of the former, a bit of the latter. I want to look like a comfy goth mum with a vintage twist, is that so much to ask? I’m calling it alternative retro because it’s a bit grown-up-emo, a sprinkling of 50’s and 60’s styling and more than a few band shirts thrown in.

Belle Poque – 40’s – 70s Vintage and Stylish Clothing

So Belle Poque was a place I’d never think to buy from, honestly. Whenever I’d see adverts or caught a glimpse on socials, I’d only ever see thin people in their clothes. So it was a complete surprise to me that they reached out to me; and even more so that they go up to a 2XL! The Belle Poque 2XL is said to be a UK 24-26, which is much more generous that most 2XLs on the market, so I had to give it a go!

So considering I sat on the outer cusp of their sizing, I thought I’d try out a few of their items! This is the first outfit of two, and because I wear nothing but black these days, both this top and the skirt would be awesome for wardrobe-building basics.

Ribbed Knitted Sweater

This is a great in-between-seasons knit, super soft and stretchy without being see-through. Because of the size chart, I decided to err on the side of caution and take the 2XL, but honestly I wish I’d sized down as it runs large. I do love how elegant it is, though! The shoulder pleating really makes it, and I do love a square neckline on me. I think this will look amazing with midi pencil skirts and slightly longer flared skirts to up the elegance factor.

Buttons Flared A-Line Skirt

Again, I took the 2XL in this skirt, and although the fit isn’t the worst, it’s not the best, either. I’ve mentioned before on the blog that I find skirts like this difficult to fit on my body, thanks to my hip-to-waist-ratio. As always, the waist is a bit loose and the hips/tum a bit tight. Do I personally mind? Absolutely not. And I’d say that as long as your hips don’t throw you massively off the size chart, you’ll be golden. There’s enough stretch in the bengaline fabric to accommodate tums comfortably, but it doesn’t look quite like it does on the models on the website. It’s a great little workhorse of a skirt regardless, and I’ve worn it a bunch of times since it arrived. Suits band shirts and vans just as well as boots and knitwear!

What’s your thoughts on Belle Poque?

Have you bought from them before? Maybe you’re like me and didn’t know they did larger sizing? I’d love to hear your thoughts in the comments!

A fashion post on plus size date outfits from SHEIN written by Andii Melody Mae on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a fat girl fashion blog

The post Plus Size Date Outfits with SHEIN! appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
Get loved up in style!

Well hello friends and welcome back to the blog! Yes, I made a big deal about coming back and then took another month off… I’d make more of an apology about it, but I think the whole world understands the constant burn out. But I digress, because today I want to talk to you about some amazing SHEIN dresses and plus size date outfits!!

Before I get into this post, I want to make a quick point on something — I will not be facilitating any arguments about SHEIN today. Maybe in the future I’ll finally finish the post I want to make on being fat and the discourse on fast fashion brands. But, what I will say is this; when you’re plus sized, finding clothes is difficult and regularly unaffordable when it does exist. For me, having a brand that caters to my size and creates clothes that allow plus sized people to express themselves is important. Affiliate links are also in use. (Read more about those in the disclaimer)

Plus Size Date Outfits!

Coffee Date — Rib Knit Dress

Whether it’s with your beau or your bestie, Coffee Dates are honestly my favourite! It lends itself to a bit more of a casual outfit, and this dress is perfect for the occasion! I actually ADORE this dress! Perfect knit weight, non-seethrough and keeps its shape perfectly. I wear it so often that I literally bought a second one because I never want to be without this dress.

Also comes in burgundy, light grey and a minty teal colour, for those of you that wear other colours than black these days! I took the 4XL in this and it’s perfectly true to size.

Band Night Date — Star Print Bishop Sleeve Dress

If you’re not being taken to your other half’s mate’s dad’s band on a Tuesday night, you clearly haven’t lived! Band night was a staple back in the before days (remember when Covid wasn’t a thing? Yeah, me either), and sometimes you gotta glam it up a little.

This little number can be dressed up or down (I think it’d look cute even worn over jeans!), comes in six different colours, and wears like a dream. I love the deep curved neckline and the bishop sleeves, and the metallic foil print adds a really great shimmer. The fabric isn’t too static-y and fits nicely in the 4XL on me, if I wanted a tighter/less floaty fit the size down could’ve worked, but I do like the fit of this.

Fancy Date — Dobby Mesh Sleeve Dress

Pinkies out, let’s get fancy! I was actually planning on wearing this exact outfit to the theatre recently — can you imagine using those little opera glasses with this dress? Super fancy. Believe it or not, The Fiancé® actually chose this dress for that exact reason.

To be completely honest with you, I could’ve easily taken a size down in this dress due to its stretch nature (who knew it’d have stretch?), and I think it would have been a lot nicer on. I’m not a massive fan of fake button-downs, and this one is a little disappointing in that it’s just buttons sewn down the front. Some may not care about that at all, and it is a lovely dress, that’s just a personal bugbear of mine!

Again took the 4XL, and would say that you can size down if you’re smaller in the bust and waist.

Spicy Date – Sequin Wrap Cami Dress

Hehe, spicyyyyy. Can you tell I spend way too much time on TikTok these days? But anyway — got a date where you want to absolutely DAZZLE someone? This beaut of a dress will do exactly that!

This dress does exactly what it says on the tin. A spaghetti-strap wrap dress that’s one side velvet and one side sequin. I absolutely love it, and it’s soft and beautiful on. Took the 4XL, and although I don’t mind the sizing, it’s a little tighter on my hips than I’d like. I think I can add some hooks and eyes to keep it in place, though.

No Date At All… — Sheer Belted Dress

Oooooh boy, what a beauty this is! I have a real affinity for over the top sorts of lingerie/nightwear thanks to my pinup days. And this is a lovely sheer dress that looks good over nothing at all, but also anything at all! Perfect for getting in and out of easily… if ya know what I mean ;).

4XL taken again, and sizing is on point!

What do we think of these plus size date outfits?

Got any dates coming up? What are you wearing? Let me know in the comments! And remember you can use code; MELODYMAE for 15% off!

Remember to follow me on Instagram and Facebook for daily outfits in my stories, on Pinterest for my inspirations and on Twitter to read my thoughts on a semi-regular basis!

item.content:encoded:
Anyone else got ‘into the thick of it’ stuck in their head now?

Happy Sunday, folks! How are we doing? Hopefully your first week of 2022 has been productive and/or just a good time! I started strong with a Big Clean in my flat, and ended up a bit broken by the end of the week and struggled with getting myself co-ordinated. The joys of a mental health struggle, really! But I digress, how about some handmade plus size style for you this week?

Soooo these photos are actually from the end of November, and if I’m completely honest, I really didn’t like the photos. It’s been a while since I stood in front of a camera, and the photos show how rusty I was! Also how rusty The Fiancé® is with the camera, bless. I hadn’t taken photos of myself since mid October, and I can’t say I’m particularly happy with how I look. I mentioned briefly in my mental health post that I’ve been suffering from some hair loss in my fringe. These photos show the hair loss off pretty well, which sucks to look at, naturally. So I sat on the images for a while. It’s hard when your outer image doesn’t match what you think, and can be difficult to look at when there’s body changes you’re less than happy about. But I suppose this is all about true acceptance!

Handmade Plus Size Style

Aside from my own bullshit about my body and hair loss, there was a point to this post, I promise! I made a thing! I had some time off in November and decided to force some creativity to help me out with the ol’ depression. Spoiler alert; it did not work. But I got a cute skirt out of it!

I wish I could say anything specific about the construction of this skirt that would actually be interesting to read — but the reality is that it’s another dirndl skirt. I love a dirndl skirt for a quick make, since it’s literally one of the easiest things to make! One day I’ll do a full tutorial on how to make these, because it’s a great project for those that are getting into sewing clothes.

So a dirndl skirt is literally a rectangle of fabric that is either gathered or, in my case, pleated to fit a waistband. This skirt has large box pleats and a half-elastic waistband. That’s literally all there is to this skirt, honestly! I actually made it WAY too big, and have half a mind to take it apart and start again so that it fits better in the waist. You know what I will most likely not do? Take it apart and start again. Even if the pockets are too low, I added the elastic to the wrong side of the waistband and it’s still a bit too large. It’s a lesson in dealing with it, right?

What do you think of this handmade plus size style?

It’s nice to get back to blogging, honestly — and even though this post doesn’t exactly have a lot of… uhhh, point? It’s good to get back into the swing of it. Hope you’re all doing well out there!

item.title: 2021 In Review; Turned out 2020 Could Get Worse!
item.dc:creator: Melody Mae
item.description:
2021 In Review, a round up post on the year, written by Andii Melody Mae on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a fat girl fashion blog

The post 2021 In Review; Turned out 2020 Could Get Worse! appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
Happy New Year, darlings!

It’s the end of another year, and as I say every year — where the hell did it go? I feel like I blinked and August turned to Christmas Day. And now it’s the end of the year, and whilst people gear up to have a New Year’s Eve party or… whatever people do on NYE, I’m gearing up to consume garlic bread and bourbon and give a middle finger to Another Shitty Year. Here’s 2021 In Review, a little look at my year.

2021 In Review

Covid, Cancer and Mental Health Struggles

Let’s start off with The Bad Stuff, huh? 21 months later from the first lockdowns and guess what; covid still rules the roost. It’s difficult to be completely positive about the year when you spent a lot of it inside and even more fearful of it than 2020. But vaccines are now available, and with them comes a little more freedom, I suppose.

Of the worst things to hear in general, my mum was diagnosed with bladder cancer back in May. She’s a fighter and it was found quickly, though. She had a round of chemo and a long course of radiotherapy, and although we’re not fully out of the woods, she’s definitely doing better. Fingers crossed in the new year we get more concrete news and can move on from this, though! This is possibly the only part of my life I’m staying hopeful of, to be honest with you.

Mental health struggles? Yeah, we’ve spoken about that in the last post, didn’t we? It’s not been an easy year for my noggin, honestly. I’ve become pretty isolated through covid fears and home working and being a bit useless. To add to that, TikTok has made me realise a lot of my personality quirks might actually be ADHD, which is a whole other thing to look into in the next year.

New Additions and New Positions

It wasn’t all doom and gloom though! My job changed in January last year — I took over the Social Media channels at work whilst we found a new Social Media Manager and started working from home. It was a welcome change from being furloughed and just waiting for the world to re-open. I ended up staying on as we closed our Covent Garden store, and now my job’s super diverse. I now get to work from home, work on my photography skills and learn new things all the time. That’s pretty cool!

As well as new positions, as a family we welcomed two adorable new Nephews! As my nieces grow into Actual Human Adults, it’s nice to have some babies to add to the mix. And of course — my personal highlight of 2021 was welcoming a little black kitten to our household! Bear was found in a tree and ended up moving in with us in September, and now my life (and hands) will never be the same. He’s a tiny nightmare, a sweet baby boy and my joy, honestly. Having him keeps me on my toes, gives me more structure to my day and makes working from home easier. As someone that’s never owned a pet of their own, it’s a lot of learning, and I wouldn’t change it for the world.

Family Time and Doing Stuff

So I spent the beginning of 2021 quarantined with my brother and sister in law due to her having covid. I also spent time with them and my mum during her first two weeks of chemo and a few decent breaks back home, too. I actually spent a lot of time with my family this year! Me and my sister in law spent a good few days down the beach together, and that’s something I’ve really missed since lockdown. We’ve all become a lot closer, and I honestly look back at summer with a lot of yearning. Take me back to fish and chips on the beach!

Some Cool Shit Happened!

It’s kinda funny, when I look back at 2021, I feel like nothing good happened. But honestly? So many cool things did happen! I turned 30, which was alright! I got to model a new range for Vendula London in the beginning of the year, too, which was cool. Although, to be honest maybe should have happened before my fifth year of employment ;). I got to be part of and model for the size expansion from Revival Retro, which was a bit of an honour. Earlier in the year, I was also featured in an issue of Simply Sewing about plus size sewing. This was so exciting, especially when I saw how much I featured in the segment! I felt a little fraudulent, of course, because I haven’t sewn much recently, but it was still pretty fucking cool.

On the subject of sewing and modelling, I was also part of some incredible projects in 2021! Firstly, I was the plus size model for Tilly And The Buttons’ Skye and Iris patterns! TATB expanded their sizing in 2021, and I finally got to use a TATB pattern because of this — and I can recommend them wholeheartedly. Such great patterns with super easy-to-follow instructions.

And then — in literally the same weekend — I also modelled for the most incredible plus size sewing book from Cashmerette, Ahead of The Curve! Although I’ve yet to make anything from the book myself, I end up looking through it a lot just to absorb all the fit knowledge. If you haven’t yet, have a look at my book review to learn more.

Sewing and Creativity

I’ve actually not made much this year, sadly. My style’s changed a bit, my motivation has been elsewhere, and I’m also a bit of a lazy boy. But I did make a few dresses, all of which were gingham — who would’ve guessed?! But I’ve been creative in different ways throughout the year. I’ve been painting more, working on my bullet journal skills, painted and redecorated a whole living room and learnt a whole new skill! Funnily enough, weaving has to be a new favourite pastime, as it requires less active thought and a bit more mindless activity, which is good for a brain like mine! Although that reminds me that I need to finish my autumn woven scene soon…

And That’s My 2021 In Review… How Was Yours?

I’d love to hear about your year, things you’ve done/learned and how you feel about the new year in general!

I’m not one for resolutions at the new year, but one of my general intentions is to blog more, so hopefully we see each other more in 2022!

I hope 2022 is a better, safer and stronger year for everyone!

Remember to follow me on Instagram and Facebook for daily outfits in my stories, on Pinterest for my inspirations and on Twitter to read my thoughts on a semi-regular basis!

item.title: The Joys of the Mental Health Struggle
item.dc:creator: Melody Mae
item.description:
A blog post on The Mental Health Struggle on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a plus size blog written by Andii Melody Mae

The post The Joys of the Mental Health Struggle appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
Well. Um, hi!!

It’s been a hot minute, hasn’t it? My last post was in mid October and my last Instagram post was at the end of October. A time, indeed. It’s been an unexpected hiatus of blogging, and honestly? There’s been just no spark to actually do anything outside of existing the last two months. That’s the joys of mental health struggles, right?

Hooray for the Mental Health Struggle

Between my regular depression, seasonal depression and pandemic depression, I’ve honestly been knocked off my feet in the emotions department. My life is literally sleep, eat, work, hang out with a kitten and play Animal Crossing. I barely speak to my friends, rarely leave the house for non-work related things, and generally am just bleak as fuck. The willpower to create content, make things or even just write has been MIA for a bit. However, I feel like I’m pulling through a bit, making a bit of a breakthrough and slowly crawling back to being myself.

I’m not alone when I say that I’m still living in fear, that I’m still holding life to a stop until this ‘all blows over’ — if it ever will. But it’s also given me a lot of excuses to be the worst version of myself; one that has no social interaction, that has become agoraphobic and generally just a bit sucky. Of course, it’s all for the right reasons. I stay home to protect myself, I wear a mask to protect others. I’m triple-vaxxed, regularly testing and being as careful as I can be (I’ve had like three blips of being bad with mask wearing, and they were all entered around alcohol…). But I feel like I’ve given myself too much leeway to giving into my depression; ‘it’s okay that you’re not looking after yourself, it’s a pandemic!’ can only go so far, you know?

Being better for Myself

So I’m probably going to take the rest of the Christmas/New Year break off of socials still. I’m probably going to eat my weight in Christmas food, be merry, get drunk and have a good old time. I will use it as a reset button — staying away from all those ‘new year’s resolutions’ bullshit promises — and be better for myself. Still safe, obviously. It’s still a pandemic, after all. But I need to stop wearing pyjamas 24/7, eating takeaways 7 nights a week and disregarding my health.

Why did I feel a need to post a whole blog post on some self-serving bullshit? Who knows. I can certainly use the excuse ‘it’s my blog, get over it’, though. And maybe just writing out my thoughts and feelings will finally give me the push I need to actually get off my arse and do something about it? Again, who knows.

Whatever you’re up to over the holiday season — remember to be good to yourself!

What I do know is this, my darlings — stay safe. Be good to yourself, whether that’s allowing yourself a break or kicking yourself up the arse. You deserve love and kindness, and you also deserve to be the best version of yourself. Remember to brush your teeth, wash your face and tell yourself that you love you. Because I love you too.

Have a wonderful Christmas/New Year/General Holiday Time, and we’ll see you for a lot more fashion and maybe a little less depression in 2022!

item.title: Ahead of the Curve by Cashmerette; Plus Size Sewing
item.dc:creator: Melody Mae
item.description:
A look at the new plus size sewing book, Ahead of the Curve by Cashmerette -- written by Andii Melody Mae on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a fat girl fashion blog

The post Ahead of the Curve by Cashmerette; Plus Size Sewing appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
Plus size sewists; welcome to your brand new bible!

Hey friends! How are we doing this week? I’m struggling with the change in weather, but the smell of autumn evenings are keeping me above water. That and the cat, but we’ve gone over my crazy cat lady in last week’s blurb. Today, instead, I wanted to talk about a project I modelled for back in April! And so here’s a little first look at the first ever book by the gorgeous and talented Jenny Rushmore. So here’s a look at Ahead of the Curve by Cashmerette!

Before we get into this; I’m always trying to be as open as possible where my posts come from and things that I may or may not have been given. I was a paid model for Ahead of the Curve, and was given the book in advance because of this. I am not paid to promote this book, and am posting on my own accord because I truly love the book and want everyone to own one! You can always see my disclaimer page for any other information.

Ahead of the Curve by Cashmerette

If you’re a plus size person who sews, you’ve heard of Cashmerette. Chances are, you may even half half a wardrobe of their lovely patterns, because for the longest time it was the only place you could find plus size sewing patterns. I’ve been following the brand for a long time, but hadn’t taken the step to making one of their patterns before. Do I have a reason? Absolutely not; I can still see myself in about 100 versions of the Upton dress!

But for the uninitiated or the non-sewing people reading this; Cashmerette is a sewing pattern company based in Massachusetts that specialises in sizes UK16-36 (US12-32). Run by Jenny Rushmore, a plus-sized sewist who believes that well fitting clothes should be for everyone, regardless of size. And now she’s written a book!

Fit Clinics For Every Body Type

The bulk of Ahead of the Curve is about fit — the tagline on the back reads ‘change your clothes to fit your body’ — and it’s broken down into great little ‘Fit Clinics’ throughout the book. From busts, shoulders, arms and even tums, bums and thighs — this book will show you how to adjust your sewing for every part of your body. The fit clinics are written neutrally, which means that different ways of a body aren’t held in higher esteem than others. It’s so refreshing to read about Flat Bum Adjustments without any

One of the most amazing things I saw whilst reading through the book was this page; Fitting if you use mobility aids. As someone who’s mostly able bodied and doesn’t need to use mobility aids, I’ve never really thought of that in terms of sewing. Although it’s only a page in a book, it doesn’t feel like an afterthought. It was really good to see, and also helps educate abled-bodied people; which is always a plus!

Five Plus Size Patterns Included

There’s five included patterns in the book, in which the Fit Clinics are based around — but they could easily be interchanged and hacked to be whatever you want! You can see the Honeybourne Dress that I modelled, which was made in a signature look for me — gingham! But as well as that dress, there is the knit-loving Foxhill dress modelled by Emily @Notinator. The Kersoe top modelled by Miranda @Mirry_Maker. Then there’s the Stanway t-shirt modelled by Corrie @ceramic67. And even some trousers with the Magna pants modelled by Dibs @DibsAndTheMachine.

All the models are also sewists themselves — and Ahead of the Curve even includes a page of interviews with each of us! We get to talk about our bodies, sewing for them and a bit of our sewing history!

Ahead of the Curve is out in the UK now!

You can buy the book in the UK and pre-order for other countries in the following places (although do try and support your local businesses if you can!);

  • Amazon UK
  • Bookshop.org
  • A chain like Waterstones
  • Your local independent bookstore
  • Or, you can order directly from Cashmerette (the book will be sent from the USA)

Remember to follow me on Instagram and Facebook for daily outfits in my stories, on Pinterest for my inspirations and on Twitter to read my thoughts on a semi-regular basis!

item.title: Favourites From the Vendula London AW21 Collection!
item.dc:creator: Melody Mae
item.description:
A post on the Vendula London AW21 Collection written by Andii Melody Mae on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a fat girl fashion blog

The post Favourites From the Vendula London AW21 Collection! appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
Let’s talk about HANDBAGS!

Hello friends! How are we doing at the moment? Enjoying the start of Autumn at all? My life is honestly working and kitten rearing and nothing else, so I can’t say I’m doing much at the moment. However, on the subject of work, it’s been a while since I showed off some Vendula products — so why not show you my favourites from the Vendula London AW21 Collection?

Before we get to the beautiful handbags — I obviously work for Vendula London. It’s in my Disclaimer, even! I actually took these photos in our studio, in front of our little archive wall (gotta brand those photos!) of bags of Vendula past. I don’t think a single one of them is available any more, please don’t message me, haha!

House of Jazz Grab Bag

I love a black handbag. I love a black handbag with red accents. A black handbag with red accents AND cats playing instruments? You know I’m down with this 100%. And the really cool thing about the Vendula London AW21 Collection is that the doors you see on the larger bags? They all open!

This is the Grab Bag style, back with the clasp that makes it super easy to use one-handed; I liked the zipped versions we’ve had for a few seasons, but this is my personal favourite. When I first started working for Vendula, the fact that the Grab Bag handle comes off so you can use the crossbody strap really blew my mind, so it’s always worth mentioning!

Animal Park Ostrich Tote Bag

Last season we had Animal Park with Flamingoes and Giraffes; but this season is Ostriches and Lemurs! As good as Larry the Lemur is, something about Ola the Ostrich really resonates with me. This tote is super cute and is a lot bigger than you’d imagine! And with a removable pouch on the inside, perfect for a day-to-day bag.

Highland Fling Tote Bag

Okay, this is actually my second favourite in the Highland Fling range. My favourite was the Nessie shaped bag, but it was also our customers favourite and sold out! But the Tote Bag is a good second place — tartan! Stag! Flowers! And some red! Honestly, the whole range is super cute, I just really like that this is a fairly simple bag that is still decorative and beautiful.

Bistro De Vendula Square Crossbody Bag

I’ll be honest — this was not my favourite range of the season. But after six months of staring at it to prep for socials, (yes, I know what we’re doing up to a year in advance and no I won’t tell you what’s coming, haha!) it’s definitely grown on me! This photo doesn’t show it off well, but the base is a beautiful light gold colour that honestly looks good with anything, and I really like the laser-cut awning on it. And poodles. There’s a lot of poodles on this and it’s adorable.

The Square Crossbody is a newer style for us, and as I’ve gotten older and my style has changed a bit, I really like more hands free styles. This is the lightest, most flexible shopfront bag we do, so it’ll be great for people that struggle with the weight of some of the fancier bags we make!

Heritage Georgian Floral Shopper

Do you see those handles? They’re super long, which means it’s perfect for fat arms! That’s right, I get to tell the design team to think of the fatties when we design products. This shopper style in particular is also designed with coat-wearing in mind, so there’s a whole bunch of room. I think this is a super pretty bag, structured enough but still flexible, a bit understated in design for us, but still visually interesting. It’s got a whole romantic feel that I really like.

Library Bookworm Backpack

Am I Bookworm? Honestly no, I’m horrendous at finishing books as an adult because I most likely have ADHD and either I read a novel in one go or read a chapter and never revisit it. Do I still love this Bookworm Backpack? Absolutely! The marble print is cute, the cat studs are cuter and this is an ideal size backpack to use daily. If I wasn’t already using an Easy Going bag for work, I’d probably be using this one!

Fortune Teller Charlotte Bag

Okay. I photographed this horrendously, because it’s a lot more purple in person! This is a really exciting design to see us do, honestly. A little bit witchy, very purple and some lurex, which is always nice to see in modern items.

Zodiac Gemini Pouch

The Zodiac range is a bit close to my heart, since I did the creative direction for the website images, including painting that night sky background! I’m also a sucker for black glitter and a little bit of astrology. There’s a pouch and matching mirror key charm for every zodiac sign (apart from ophiuchus, because fuck that particular sign for suddenly popping up) and I think that’ll be a great present bundle for people’s birthdays!

Obviously as a newly-crowned Crazy Black Cat Lady, I’m super excited that my star sign is two black kitties!

Vendula Ghoulevard Book Bag

This is a super fresh bag that I’m straight up obsessed with! From the BRAND NEW Vendula Ghoulevard range — this Book Bag is 1. red 2. spooky 3. just super cute. I do love the Haunted House designs as well of course, but the Grace bag literally sold out in a matter of hours so I couldn’t post that photo, haha! I can’t wait for mine to arrive at home, honestly, I’ll be using it all the time!

What are you favourites from the Vendula London AW21 Collection?

item.content:encoded:
It’s Autumn, baby!

Or as our friends over the pond say, it’s Fall! Fall’s a real cute way of naming Autumn, but you can’t beat the word ‘Autumnal’ right? There’s already been too many mentions of the word autumn in this blurb alone — it’ll lose all meaning by the end of this post. But anyway! Seasons are changing, the weather is about to be depressing for at least six months, and it’s nearly time for All The Holidays! So today I’m going to share a little plus size autumn style wishlist for you all!

a // b // c // d // e // f // g // h // i // j // k

Plus Size Autumn Style

As much as I always end up missing summer around this time, I do love autumn a whole lot. Darker colours are easier to wear (and I do have a penchant for black), and cosy nights and bonfire smells are some of my favourite things in the world. Even forgetting good old Spooky Season, I think everything that autumn has to offer is wonderful.

Even autumn clothing is great — you don’t need to wear your heaviest coats yet, it’s perfect jumper season. My go-to autumnal look is a black turtleneck with a tartan skirt — either mini or midi — paired with some knee-high boots and a beret. Literal perfection in an outfit, as far as I’m concerned! I love blackwatch tartan, so the Banned Sweet Check skirt is a winner; but I do love the classic houndstooth with a twist from Timeless, too.

I’m also slightly obsessed with the dreamy styles of Loud Bodies, like the Komako dress above. Their clothing is gorgeous and fully sustainable, which I adore. Personally their prices are above my affordability, but that doesn’t mean that it’s not worth it! Just imagine swanning around in crunchy autumn leaves in a dress like that!

What’s your autumn wishlist looking like?

I’d love to hear it in the comments below, and check out my other wishlists here!

The post Late Summer Plus Size Hell Bunny Haul! appeared first on MelodyMae.co.uk.
item.content:encoded:
Transition seasons suck; and make for the most interesting collections of clothing!

Hello friends and welcome back to the blog! I’ve been a bit pro-occupied over the last two weeks, since we welcomed our tiny little black kitten to our home! He came to us last Sunday after being with his rescue aunts for a few weeks. So me and The Fiancé® have spent most of our spare time getting the flat kitten-ready; and then just being obsessed with him. Literally obsessed! Cat-owner friends, do you ever stop being obsessed with your cat? But I digress; this is a fashion blog, is it not? Let’s talk about some late summer plus size Hell Bunny outfits!

These items were gifted in return for a review and images. Opinions are my own, I’m not paid to say anything in particular. Some links may be affiliate links, it just means I might get a few quid if you buy through my links. You can read more in my disclaimer.

Melonie Jumpsuit

Okay, hear me out here. Yes, it may be a little late for a sleeveless jumpsuit with melons on. BUT, we keep having random hot days that were better than most of the UK’s summer; so I’ll eke out the summer vibes for as long as I possibly can. I am honestly shocked at how this looks on me, honestly. As a person with a big belly, I’ve not worn trousers outside of pyjama bottoms for years now. They aren’t comfortable, they don’t look good. And then there’s this jumpsuit, which has just the right amount of room in the tum and hips to fit my 60″ hips without being tight, or giving me the dreaded moose knuckle. Big tum folks, you know how that is.

I took the 4XL/UK 22 in this jumpsuit — which is my usual Hell Bunny size, which is AWESOME. If you’re less hippy, I’d recommend sizing down. The Melonie Jumpsuit is now £29.99 in the sale, too! Sizes XS-6XL.

Barbed Wire Mini Dress

I’m still really loving some alternative style, and Hell Bunny is actually one of my go-tos for plus size alt style, too! There’s really a lack of brands doing plus size alternative clothing, sadly. But I do love how Hell Bunny have both my styles readily available up to a size UK26.

This barbed wire print is really striking, you almost don’t notice its barbed wire at first glance, which is cool. It’s the perfect mini length, above the knee, but not too short that your arse is exposed if you even lean slightly forward. I love the waist tie details so much! Again, took the 4XL/22 in this dress and it fits pretty on point.

Cherry Bon Bon Dress

Does anyone remember Kyary Pamyu Pamyu? She had a song called Cherry Bonbon, and that’s been in my head ever since I tried this dress on! It’s a lovely little throw-on shirt dress with a typical rockabilly vibe, with scallop and cherry detailing. This dress will be a great little workhorse outfit, since it’s made from that kind of suiting-style fabric that just looks good forever. My only gripe is that there isn’t any pockets on this one!

The Cherry Bon Bon Dress is now £29.99 in the sale! Available in sizes XS-6XL. I’m wearing the 4XL/UK22 and the sizing is pretty perfect. I’ve got a teeny bit of stretching at the full bust point on the buttons, but it’s no where near as noticeable in real life.

Petals 50’s Dress

Hell Bunny’s 50s Dress style is genuinely one of my favourite styles they’ve done. I have an old version in a rose print, and it’s just such a beautiful style. I love the neckline, which suits my body type incredibly — shoutout to my broad-shouldered brethren! It’s just a gorgeous style that suits me well, looks incredible on and feels very put together regardless of what you style with it. If there’s one style you ever going to buy from Hell Bunny, make it this one!

Sizes are pretty spot on, although I can still fit in my old 3XL/UK20 version, so smaller busts could probably size down for a nice tight fit.

Plus Size Hell Bunny

Do you buy from Hell Bunny’s plus sizes at all? Did you know they’d extended the majority of their sizing to a 6XL/UK26? Let me know in the comments!

A sewing post on a plus size Lyra dress from Tilly and The Buttons written by Andii Melody Mae on MelodyMae.co.uk -- a fat girl fashion blog

item.content:encoded:
I’d call this ‘Last of the summer gingham’ but I’ve already named a dress that.

Hello friends! How are we all doing? It’s been a few weeks since my last post — well, because honestly I’m having a crisis in whether or not I want to carry on having a traditional blog. Doing the whole blogger/influencer thing in a world where social media is actively working against you sucks. I do enjoy writing and doing little photoshoots for my blog, however, so maybe things aren’t so bad. And today I wanted to show off something I’ve made for once! So here is my plus size Lyra dress from Tilly and the Buttons.

Tilly and the Buttons Lyra Dress

When the Lyra pattern was released back in April — I was instantly in love. I love a shirtdress, and have done for years. Usually I go for a 50s shirtdress styles with massive ol’ skirts attached, but there was something about the floaty skirt and bishop sleeve that I was nigh-on obsessed with. Of course, since it’s me — I had to make it in a light gingham fabric!

I actually cut out the entirety of this dress back in May. I even filmed the whole of the cutting out for a reel I was planning on doing. And then… it sat there. Until the end of August, when I finally got my arse into gear and sat down and made the whole thing in just over two days.

I’ve never actually made a Tilly and the Buttons pattern before, even though I’ve followed Tilly’s journey since her early blogging days. I’ve always just been outside of their pattern sizing. But with the addition of the UK16-32 size range, I finally can get the TATB style I’ve always loved! The Buttons’ style is super cute; much lighter, floatier and looser than my usual style, and something I’m playing around with more recently.

Being my first TATB pattern, I decided to do something I don’t usually do — which is actually follow the instructions for once, haha! I’m a nightmare for actually following patterns instructions usually, but these were so straight-forward and easy to follow! I’d definitely recommend their patterns for beginner sewists to dip their toes into more intermediate projects; I haven’t made a shirt collar since 2010 at least, and it made putting it together a real breeze.

Tilly and The Buttons Plus Size

For sizing, I cut the TATB size ’11’; which is roughly a UK26, based off my bust measurement more than anything else. I’m usually a UK22/24, and the bust of this fits perfectly, but I definitely should have graded down to the size ’10’ on the waist and arm scythe. I figured a blousey look was absolutely fine with this style, though — so I’m not exactly mad at it. It’s certainly a comfortable fit! The TATB ’10’ / UK24 would probably fit perfectly, so there’s a good amount of ease added into the pattern, so feel free to size down if you’re in between sizes!

The amusing part is that I added in a whole bunch of these vintage celluloid buttons to combat gaping in the button stand — and it’s big enough that I don’t really need those buttons to get in on! And the hardest part of this entire make was the damned buttonholes, so that was accidentally wasted time!

It’s a lovely dress, honestly. I feel a bit weird about it though — I’m not really sure exactly why it feels weird on me, but I literally left editing the photos and doing the post for over a week because I just felt so strange about it. Maybe it’s a follow on from my body issues I’m having at the moment. Maybe it’s just it’s a different style of dress? Who knows, honestly. The more I look at these photos, the more I like how it looks on me; and it’s such a floaty, comfortable dress, I’m really happy I’m warming to it more!

Does that ever happen to you? You spend the time making something, then suddenly there’s a disconnect between how much you wanted it and how much you don’t love it on?

What do you think of my gingham Lyra dress?

Have you made a Lyra dress? Or maybe you don’t sew and want to try? I’d love to hear all about it in the comments! And you can also see me modelling the Tilly and the Buttons Skye Dress here!
